Einstein's quantum riddle, also known as the EPR paradox, is a thought experiment proposed by Albert Einstein, Boris Podolsky, and Nathan Rosen in 1935. The paradox is a challenge to the principles of quantum mechanics, which were still a relatively new and controversial theory at the time.

The paradox begins with the idea of entangled particles. When two particles are entangled, their properties become linked in a way that is not fully understood. For example, if two entangled particles are created with opposite spins, then measuring the spin of one particle will immediately determine the spin of the other particle, regardless of the distance between them.

Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen argued that this violated the principle of locality, which states that information cannot travel faster than the speed of light. They proposed a scenario in which two entangled particles were created, and then separated by a large distance. They then argued that if the spin of one particle was measured, the other particle's spin would be determined instantaneously, regardless of the distance between them. They argued that this violated the principle of locality, and that some hidden variable must be responsible for the apparent non-locality.

The EPR paradox has been the subject of much debate and study in the decades since it was proposed. It played a role in the development of quantum mechanics and has helped to shape our understanding of the nature of reality at the most fundamental level.
